title_sort: maria smith to walt whitman, 14 march 1875
title: Maria Smith to Walt Whitman, 14 March 1875
text: From Bethuel's MotherQueensbury,March, the 14 75Dear friendireceived[I received] your kind letter some time ago iwas[I was] truly glad to hear from you iwas[I was] sick and am not well now itook[I took] aheavy[a heavy] cold had the Doctor Called once ihave[I have] some Cough yet but go around the house and sit up the most of the time on inhopes[in hopes] of going out in afew[a few] days we got Bethuels[Bethuel's] papers and your picture and sent all the things overto[over to] him we all see the picture and was very much pleased to see it Mary said that is the man that saved our brother's life to one of our neighbours Mary and David has gone to Mrs Smith (Bethuel's Mother)her brother, Halsey Smiths avisiting[a visiting] now they will go to their boat the last of the month he says he will try and find you when he goes to philadelphia[Philadelphia] perhaps you will see them both this summer Bethuels[Bethuel's] youngest little boy has ben[been] scalded with tea on his stomach they sent for the Doctor that is the last we have heard that is akind[a kind] hearted little boy and agood[a good] child ilove[I love] him you mail your letters right we live in the south west part of the town if you should mail your letterQueensbury it would go to the north part avillage[a village] by the[by the] name of the rider we dont go there once ayear[a year] i[I] thank you for all your presents you sent me I read with interest and thought of our kind friend although far away perhaps we all may see eachother[each other] yet our Children are anxious to see you the picture you sent Bethuel looks some like my grandfather, Deen that is my fathers father if Harvy Albero and Sally should go to philadelphia[Philadelphia] They will find you ishould[I should] like to have your picture Bethuel has got the one you sent to his father and me iwas[I was] to Halsey Smith when irote[I wrote] the other letter to you istayed[I stayed] there several days they live about two miles from glensfalls[Glens Falls] iwent[I went] to meeting one Sunday evening and enjoyed my meting[meeting] first-rate there was 1 Captised and sevral[several] more received in ful[full] fellowships with the Church there has ben[been] a reformation to gens falls[Glens Falls] this winter irejoiced[I rejoiced] to see it the evening iwas[I was] there they sung old fashioned hymns and old tunes it seemed like old times when iwas[I was] young idont[I dont] now[know] as you can read my riting[writing] but we feel anxious to hear from you and how you get along god bless you with my best respects and love to youfrom Maria Smithto Mr Walt Whitmanyours truly Maria Smith to Walt Whitman, 14 March 1875
